claim: People in England spend more time working now than in the past.

supporting.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000.

attacks.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000.
The statistics may not account for the rise in part-time and gig economy jobs, which could skew the average without reflecting actual full-time workloads.
Studies indicate that full-time employees in traditional sectors still report longer hours, supporting the original claim despite part-time work trends.
The increase in working hours could be temporary or cyclical, influenced by economic conditions rather than a long-term trend.
Long-term labor market analyses confirm a sustained upward trend in working hours across multiple economic cycles.

supporting.text: Technological advancements have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer perceived working hours.

attacks.text: Technological advancements have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer perceived working hours.
Studies show that actual working hours in England have decreased over the past century due to labor laws and automation.
Perceived working hours may not accurately reflect actual working hours, as stress and work-life imbalance can distort perception.
Remote work has increased flexibility, allowing people to work more efficiently and reduce total working hours.
Flexibility can also lead to overwork, as employees may feel pressured to be available outside traditional hours.

supporting.text: The rise of the gig economy has resulted in more people working multiple jobs or irregular hours compared to traditional employment patterns.

attacks.text: The rise of the gig economy has resulted in more people working multiple jobs or irregular hours compared to traditional employment patterns.
The gig economy represents a small fraction of total employment, and most workers still hold traditional full-time jobs with stable hours.
Even within the gig economy, many workers choose flexible hours to balance work and personal life, which may not increase total working hours.
Automation and productivity gains have reduced the need for long working hours in many sectors, offsetting any increase from the gig economy.
Productivity gains have not uniformly reduced working hours, as employers often expect the same output in less time, increasing work intensity.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, such as inflation and stagnant wages, have forced many workers to take on additional work or overtime to maintain their standard of living.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, such as inflation and stagnant wages, have forced many workers to take on additional work or overtime to maintain their standard of living.
Technological advancements and automation have reduced the need for manual labor, allowing some workers to maintain their standard of living with less work.
Despite automation, many service-sector jobs require human presence and cannot be reduced, leading to sustained or increased working hours.
Government policies and labor laws have increasingly promoted work-life balance, reducing average working hours over time.
Enforcement of labor laws is inconsistent, and many workers, especially in gig economies, face pressure to work longer hours despite regulations.

supporting.text: Workplace flexibility and remote work options have enabled employees to work outside traditional office hours, extending total working time.

attacks.text: Workplace flexibility and remote work options have enabled employees to work outside traditional office hours, extending total working time.
Remote work often leads to better work-life balance, reducing the need for overtime or extended working hours.
Studies show that remote workers frequently work longer hours due to blurred boundaries between work and personal life.
Not all employees have access to workplace flexibility or remote work options, limiting the overall impact on working hours.
Technological advancements have increased productivity, potentially reducing the need for longer working hours.
Increased productivity often leads to higher expectations and workload, offsetting any reduction in working hours.

supporting.text: Historical data indicates that average working hours in England were higher in the early 20th century, suggesting a decrease rather than an increase over time.

attacks.text: Historical data indicates that average working hours in England were higher in the early 20th century, suggesting a decrease rather than an increase over time.
Modern work includes unpaid overtime and digital connectivity, which historical data may not fully capture.
Studies show that unpaid overtime and digital work have not significantly increased total working hours compared to historical industrial labor.
Historical data may not account for part-time work trends, which could skew comparisons.
Adjusting for part-time work still shows a net decrease in average working hours over the past century.
